title: Attack Frameworks and Methodologies
subtitle: Understanding How Attackers Operate to Build Better Defenses

daily_tasks: Prioritize threats by kill chain position
Design controls for kill chain phases

introduction.hook: When you understand how attackers think, you can anticipate their next move. Attack frameworks like the Cyber Kill Chain and MITRE ATT&CK aren't just academic exercises - they're battle-tested models that describe how real attacks unfold. SOC analysts use them to prioritize alerts (reconnaissance is less urgent than lateral movement). Incident responders use them to predict attacker behavior. Red teamers use them to plan realistic attacks. These frameworks transform chaos into understandable patterns.
learning_goals: Explain the Cyber Kill Chain phases and defensive strategies for each
Navigate the MITRE ATT&CK framework for threat analysis and detection
Apply the Diamond Model for threat attribution and analysis
Use frameworks to assess detection coverage and identify gaps
Map real-world attacks to framework phases and techniques

sections.title: The Cyber Kill Chain
sections.content:
Developed by Lockheed Martin from military doctrine, the Cyber Kill Chain describes seven phases of a targeted attack. Reconnaissance: gathering information about the target. Weaponization: creating malicious payload. Delivery: transmitting weapon to target. Exploitation: triggering the vulnerability. Installation: establishing persistence. Command & Control: establishing communication channel. Actions on Objectives: achieving the attacker's goal. Defense strategy: disrupt at the earliest possible phase - stopping reconnaissance prevents everything that follows.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: Seven phases: Reconnaissance, Weaponization, Delivery, Exploitation, Installation, C2, Actions. Additionally, Earlier disruption is more effective - stop recon to prevent everything represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: Seven phases: Reconnaissance, Weaponization, Delivery, Exploitation, Installation, C2, Actions
Earlier disruption is more effective - stop recon to prevent everything
Each phase requires different defenses: threat intel for recon, email filtering for delivery, etc.
Not all attacks follow linear progression - modern attacks may skip or repeat phases
Useful for understanding attack progression and planning defenses

mnemonics.mnemonic: RWDEICA = Recon, Weaponize, Deliver, Exploit, Install, C2, Actions
mnemonics.explanation: Seven phases of the Cyber Kill Chain
Disrupting early phases prevents later damage

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking Kill Chain only applies to APTs
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Even simple attacks follow these phases. Phishing = Recon + Deliver + Exploit + Install. Ransomware follows the same pattern.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Kill Chain applies to all attacks. Understanding phases helps defend against everything from commodity malware to APTs.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Kill Chain applies to all attacks, not just advanced threats

common_mistakes.mistake: Only defending at one Kill Chain phase
common_mistakes.why_wrong: If attackers bypass one phase's defenses, the attack succeeds. Defense in depth means controls at multiple phases.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Layer defenses across multiple Kill Chain phases. Email filtering AND endpoint protection AND network monitoring.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Defend at multiple Kill Chain phases for defense in depth

knowledge_check.question: Why is stopping an attack during the Reconnaissance phase more effective than stopping it during Command & Control?
knowledge_check.answer: Stopping reconnaissance prevents all subsequent phases - the attacker never progresses. Stopping C2 means exploitation and installation already occurred.
knowledge_check.explanation: Earlier intervention prevents more damage. By C2 phase, the attacker has already compromised systems.

sections.title: MITRE ATT&CK Framework
sections.content:
MITRE ATT&CK (Adversarial Tactics, Techniques, and Common Knowledge) is a comprehensive knowledge base of real-world attacker behaviors. Unlike the Kill Chain's seven phases, ATT&CK provides 14 tactics (goals) containing hundreds of specific techniques (methods). Tactics answer 'why' (persistence, privilege escalation). Techniques answer 'how' (scheduled task, token manipulation). This granularity enables precise detection engineering - you can build detections for specific techniques rather than general attack phases.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: 14 Tactics (goals): Initial Access through Impact. Additionally, Hundreds of Techniques (methods) under each tactic represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: 14 Tactics (goals): Initial Access through Impact
Hundreds of Techniques (methods) under each tactic
Sub-techniques provide even more specific detail
Real-world based: derived from actual threat intelligence
Enables detection engineering: build rules for specific techniques

mnemonics.mnemonic: 14 Tactics from Initial Access to Impact
mnemonics.explanation: ATT&CK covers the full attack lifecycle

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Tactics are goals (persistence). Techniques are methods (scheduled task). One tactic has many techniques.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Tactic = what attacker wants to achieve. Technique = specific method to achieve it.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Tactics are goals; Techniques are methods

common_mistakes.mistake: Trying to detect all ATT&CK techniques
common_mistakes.why_wrong: There are hundreds of techniques. Not all apply to your environment. Prioritize based on threat intelligence and your assets.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Prioritize detection for techniques used by threats relevant to your industry and environment.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Focus on techniques relevant to your threat landscape

knowledge_check.answer: A tactic is the attacker's goal (like 'Persistence'), while a technique is a specific method to achieve that goal (like 'Scheduled Task')
knowledge_check.explanation: Tactics describe WHY attackers do something; techniques describe HOW they do it.

sections.title: The Diamond Model
sections.content:
The Diamond Model analyzes intrusions through four interconnected features: Adversary (who), Capability (how/what tools), Infrastructure (where - IPs, domains), and Victim (target). These form a diamond shape with adversary and victim on the vertical axis, capability and infrastructure on the horizontal. The model excels at threat intelligence and attribution - understanding the relationship between attacker groups, their tools, and infrastructure helps predict future attacks and attribute incidents.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: Four core features: Adversary, Capability, Infrastructure, Victim. Additionally, Relationships between features enable analysis and attribution represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: Four core features: Adversary, Capability, Infrastructure, Victim
Relationships between features enable analysis and attribution
Adversary-Victim: targeting relationship
Capability-Infrastructure: tools and where they're hosted
Used for threat intelligence and attribution, not real-time detection

mnemonics.explanation: Four corners of the Diamond Model

mnemonics.mnemonic: Diamond = Attribution and Intelligence (who did it, how)
mnemonics.explanation: Primary use case for the Diamond Model

common_mistakes.mistake: Using Diamond Model for real-time detection
common_mistakes.why_wrong: Diamond Model is for analysis and attribution after the fact, not for building detection rules.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Use ATT&CK for detection engineering. Use Diamond Model for threat intelligence and attribution.

common_mistakes.mistake: Focusing only on one Diamond feature
common_mistakes.why_wrong: The model's power is in relationships between features. Knowing adversary without infrastructure provides incomplete picture.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Analyze all four features and their relationships for comprehensive threat understanding.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Diamond Model value is in feature relationships

sections.title: Applying Frameworks in Practice
sections.content:
Frameworks become powerful when applied together. Map incidents to Kill Chain phases to understand progression and prioritize response. Use ATT&CK to build specific detections and assess coverage gaps. Apply Diamond Model for attribution and threat intelligence. Red teams use frameworks to plan realistic attacks and identify defensive gaps. Blue teams use them to prioritize detections and understand attacker behavior. The goal isn't academic knowledge - it's practical defensive improvement.

Understanding these concepts is critical for exam success and real-world application. Security professionals encounter these scenarios regularly, making mastery essential. The key aspects to remember include: Kill Chain: Understand attack progression, prioritize response. Additionally, ATT&CK: Build detections, assess coverage, map to threat intelligence represents another crucial element. Organizations implementing these practices see measurable improvements in their security posture. Regular review and hands-on practice reinforce these concepts for long-term retention.
key_points: Kill Chain: Understand attack progression, prioritize response
ATT&CK: Build detections, assess coverage, map to threat intelligence
Diamond Model: Attribution, threat intelligence, predict future attacks
Use together: ATT&CK techniques map to Kill Chain phases
Practical applications: Detection engineering, gap analysis, threat hunting

mnemonics.mnemonic: Kill Chain = Progression, ATT&CK = Detection, Diamond = Attribution
ATT&CK techniques map to Kill Chain phases

common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Apply frameworks to daily work: map alerts to ATT&CK, assess Kill Chain position, use Diamond for attribution.
common_mistakes.exam_trap: Frameworks are practical tools, not just concepts

common_mistakes.why_wrong: Each framework has different strengths. Kill Chain for progression, ATT&CK for specificity, Diamond for attribution.
common_mistakes.correct_understanding: Use frameworks together based on your goal. Different situations call for different frameworks.

knowledge_check.explanation: Kill Chain gives strategic view; ATT&CK provides tactical detail for detection and hunting.

key_takeaways: Cyber Kill Chain: 7 phases showing attack progression - defend at multiple phases
MITRE ATT&CK: Tactics (goals) contain Techniques (methods) - use for detection engineering
Diamond Model: Adversary, Victim, Infrastructure, Capability - use for attribution
Frameworks complement each other - use together based on goal
Practical applications: detection engineering, gap analysis, incident response prioritization
exam_tips: Know all 7 Kill Chain phases in order
Diamond Model = attribution, not real-time detection
Kill Chain applies to ALL attacks, not just APTs
Earlier Kill Chain disruption prevents more damage
